Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Do gut microbiota affect caterpillar herbivory and fitness?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent studies have shown that some animals, including humans, are heavily dependent on trillions of bacteria and other microorganisms that inhabit their gut ("gut microbiota") to digest food and provide nutrients. Although this microbial partnership likely occurs in all animals, it remains unexplored in most. This project assesses the role of gut microbiota in caterpillars, some of which are globally destructive crop pests and thus of major economic interest. Understanding whether caterpillars are reliant on gut microbiota for feeding and growth could help in designing strategies for controlling them more effectively. Researchers will conduct an experiment using the tobacco hornworm caterpillar, a common pest of tomato and tobacco plants. Findings of this project will advance scientific understanding of how much animals and microbes have evolved to depend on each other. This study will also provide research experience for a community college student and will engage the public through an educational workshop and a museum event.

Investigators will experimentally test the hypothesis that gut microbiota in the tobacco hornworm, Manduca sexta, affect host feeding behavior and fitness. The experiment will be based in southeastern Arizona, where a large population of wild M. sexta feed on the plant Datura wright-ii. To manipulate gut microbiota, researchers will use antibiotics to selectively remove microbes from D. wrightii without altering leaf chemical or nutritional properties. Feeding rates and development of the caterpillars, as well as fecundity of the resulting adult moths, will be measured and compared between control and antibiotic-treated groups. In addition, the size and composition of gut microbial communities will be characterized using DNA sequencing and fluorescence microscopy. Previous DNA sequencing data indicate that the number of microbes in the M. sexta gut is extremely low relative to other animals. Further, extreme chemical conditions within the caterpillar gut suggest that the gut microbes detected there are unlikely to be metabolically active. Therefore, the researchers anticipate that gut microbiota will not play a large role in host feeding or fitness. This result would challenge the current paradigm that animal growth and reproduction typically depend heavily upon microbial symbiosis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The digestive systems of humans and many other animals are inhabited by communities of microorganisms, also known as microbiomes. Recent research has shown that microbiomes can have critical roles in the normal functioning of their animal hosts, including digestion of plant fiber and provision of essential nutrients missing from the diet. Experimental removal or suppression of these microbes often results in stunted development, high mortality, or other harmful effects on host health. While it is now frequently assumed that all animals are reliant on microbiomes, there are many groups in which this has yet to be firmly established. One such group is the butterflies and moths, or Lepidoptera, whose larvae (caterpillars) are major herbivores in nature and in agriculture. This award supported an experiment testing whether gut microbes benefit the tobacco hornworm caterpillar, a common and scientifically well-studied pest of tomato and tobacco plants. In contrary to the prevailing assumption, we found that suppressing the gut microbiome using antibiotics has no negative consequences for tobacco hornworm feeding or development. This outcome can be explained by a digestive system that not only actively suppresses the growth of microbes, but also processes leaf material in a way that does not require microbial assistance. By showing that some animals do not depend on a microbiome, our findings broaden the diversity of known animal-microbe relationships and will encourage microbial investigations into other underexplored branches of the animal tree of life.

This work also has implications for applied research on economically important caterpillar pests in agriculture and managed forests. For example, caterpillars could require different control strategies from those that are effective with microbiome-dependent insects. We have established a protocol with which microbiome functions can be tested in other species of caterpillar, or in other herbivorous insects, including pest species. Additional broader impacts resulting from this project include training undergraduate students in field methods and engagement with multiple nonscientific audiences, including: the local community where the experiment was conducted, nonacademic butterfly and moth enthusiasts at conference on Lepidoptera, and schoolchildren in Boulder and Denver, CO.
